title: Phar Deserialization Vulnerability via Logging Settings

profile.name: Concrete CMS
profile.about: A simple and powerful content management system.

activities.message:
**This report has been automatically set to "needs more info"** because it does not adhere to the rules listed [on our project page](https://hackerone.com/concrete5). Please go over these rules and resubmit following the directions.

If you've read and complied with all of the rules, please email security@concrete5.org so that this issue may be reopened.

Hi Egix,
Thanks for this report! We've dealt with other reports around this functionality in the past but it seems we still have the issue of allowing paths to begin with a phar:// scheme. Would you agree removing the ability to set a path with that scheme at the beginning would be an adequate to prevent this?

Hi @korvin,

I just noticed this vulnerability is still present in Concrete5 version 8.5.5.
When are you planning to release a fixed version?
Just wanted to let you know that I'm going to request a CVE ID for this vulnerability, and will publish a security advisory on my website as soon as the CVE ID will be assigned.

Hello @egix Thanks so much for letting us know this is still present in 8.5.5. We are working on a release candidate right now and I will personally track to make sure that the remediation is included in QA testing. 

This is an awesome report! We really appreciate when reporters provide suggested solutions. In order to keep the internet safe, we would appreciate no disclosures of this vulnerability until a fix is available for the community. Thanks for being a White Hat! 

~Lisa

Hi @lisanicholson,

I'm sorry, but now it's too late, the [security advisory](http://karmainsecurity.com/KIS-2021-05) has been published yesterday.

You had seven months to fix this vulnerability, and I think it should be a more than enough timeframe to add three lines of code to solve this issue!

@egix
Hello Egidio  , We greatly appreciate the work that you put into this report. We recognize that, as an open source project with limited resources, we did not provide the regular responses that you expected. 

We value reporters like yourself helping us to make the project more secure and are committed to being better about triaging our HackerOne program! Hence me now being involved! However, we are sad that you chose to disregard the program guidelines and make the open source project LESS secure for everyone else using concrete5 by reporting the vulnerability publicly before a fix is released for the world to download. 

I will be shepherding the fix through the deployment cycle to ensure it is included in the next release. 

Sincere regards,

~Lisa

@egix 
Hello Egidio, 

A fix for this has been put into Concrete CMS release candidate 9.0.0RC1. This release is a test release for the community to debug prior to a full release in the fall. You are more than welcome to download the release candidate to confirm the fix does indeed remediate the vulnerability you reported.  ~Lisa

https://www.concretecms.com/about/blog/core-releases/concrete-cms-900rc1-now-available

Hi @lisaciso,

The current fix could be bypassed by using uppercase letters (e.g. with `PHAR://`).
Just replace `strpos` with `stripos` and you should be safe.
@egix Thanks! I've passed this on to the team that implemented the fix.

@egix Thanks again for all the work you did on reporting this vulnerability to us.
A fix for this vulnerability that you helped us remediate has been merged into these release candidates:
9.0.0RC3https://www.concretecms.com/download_file/8c1f8bf8-6e0f-4730-bfb6-649c8213f283
8.5.6RC1https://www.concretecms.com/download_file/2e714705-d861-484f-9e33-2b7ecfd7e585
It would be greatly appreciated if you could verify that we have indeed fixed the issue.

~Lisa

Hi @lisaciso,

The fix now looks good to me.

@egix   Concrete CMS 8.5.6 has been publicly released with the fix. https://documentation.concretecms.org/developers/introduction/version-history/856-release-notes. NIST has been informed to update the CVE. You are welcome to disclose.
